intro: Abies delavayi var. motuoensis, commonly known as the Motuo fir, is a rare and endemic conifer found in the high-altitude regions of China. It is characterized by its slender, conical shape and dark green, needle-like leaves. The tree produces small, oval cones that mature to a reddish-brown color. It thrives in cool, moist environments with well-drained soil. Due to its limited distribution and habitat specificity, it is considered a vulnerable species.
taxonomy_art_desc: Abies delavayi var. motuoensis belongs to the kingdom Plantae. Its phylum is Streptophyta, which includes all land plants and is characterized by the presence of true stems, leaves, and roots. Its class is Equisetopsida, which encompasses a group of vascular plants that includes ferns and horsetails, known for their complex reproductive structures. Its subclass is Pinidae, which is a group of coniferous plants that includes pines, firs, and cedars, typically with needle-like leaves and cone-bearing reproduction. Its order is Pinales, which consists of coniferous evergreen trees and shrubs, mostly with needle-like leaves and seed cones. Its family is Pinaceae, commonly known as the pine family, which includes various coniferous trees with needle-like leaves and woody cones. Its genus is Abies, which refers to the fir trees, typically characterized by their flat, needle-like leaves and cylindrical cones. Its species is Abies delavayi, a specific type of fir tree native to China, which is further divided into the variety motuoensis, found in the Motuo region.
distribution_native_art_desc: Abies delavayi var. motuoensis is primarily native to Tibet. This rare coniferous species is found in the high-altitude regions of the eastern Himalayas, particularly in the Motuo area. It thrives in cool, moist environments with well-drained soil. The plant is adapted to the rugged and mountainous terrain of the region. Its limited distribution makes it a unique and ecologically significant species in Tibetan biodiversity.
distribution_introduced_art_desc: Abies delavayi var. motuoensis was mainly introduced to the regions of Yunnan and Sichuan in China, where it thrives in high-altitude mountainous areas. It is commonly found in the Motuo Valley, a remote and ecologically significant area. This variety is known for its unique morphology and ecological adaptations to the local climate. It plays an important role in the local biodiversity and forest ecosystems. Due to its limited distribution, it is considered a rare and endemic species in these regions.
